applesauceBranMuffins.title: APPLESAUCE BRAN MUFFINS
directions: Mix dry and liquid ingredients in separate bowls.Then combine and mix gently. Don’t overmix.

ableskivers.title: AEBLESKIVERS
directions: Blend together (whisk) except egg whites. Whip egg whites into meringue. Heat pan. Fold together. Put a bit of oil or margarine before each batch.
dearAlyssa: One day you'll get that special cast-iron skillet required to make these. I don't even know if I could do it without Mom's help though, if I did have one. All I remember is you flip them with the use of a tooth pick.
And that they taste great with butter, cinnamon-sugar, maple syrup, jam, and powdered sugar.

crepes.title: CREPES
directions: Spoon small amount of batter onto lightly greased skillet. Spread batter and wait until there's no wet batter to flip. (Be careful!) Cook until slightly browned. Recommended additives: Banana, Nutella, Coconut, Butter and cinnamon-sugar, maple syrup.

quiche.title: Quiche
ingredients: 1 whole medium white or sweet(what’s the difference?) onion
directions: Crust: single shell form then cook at 425° for 5 min with weighted tin / tin foil inside to prevent bubbling. Take weight out and cook for another 5 - 7 minutes(not brown!) pull out and decrease heat to 350°.
Innards: bacon cooked on low in order to crisp well.
Cut onion in small pieces and partially sautee in small amount of bacon grease.
Combine eggs, milk, butter, and flour in a bowl and whisk until flour is not lumpy.
Layer all ingredients over crust (sprinkle some bacon bits on top for prettiness). Bake for 45 minutes at 350°

cornBread.title: Corn Bread
directions: Whisk egg, milk, and oil together.
Add flour, cornmeal, sugar, salt, and baking powder all at once. Mix until just moistened.
Pour into a greasted 9x9 pan and bake at 425° for 20 - 25 min, or until golden on top.

chickenEnchiladas.title: Chicken Enchiladas
ingredients: 1 28 oz can whole tomatoes (blend very slightly) or use crushed tomatoes
¾ to  cup sour cream or yogurt
1 16 oz can black beans (Caribbean style, drained lightly, but not rinsed)
1 ¼ cup cheddar cheese grated (save ½ for top)
10 flour (or soaked corn) tortillas (8" or fits width of pan)
directions: Mix tomatoes, tomato sauce, water, chili powder, and salt together; pour ⅓ of it over 9x13 pan.
Combine chicken, sour cream/yogurt, beans, and cheese in a bowl.
Spoon chicken mixture evenly into 10 tortillas. Roll tightly and put into pan. Pour the rest of sauce on top. Bake covered 350° for 20 min. Sprinkle rest of cheese and bake 10 more min. uncovered.
Garnish with guacamole, lettuce, olives, sour cream, tomatoes, cheese, salsa, tortilla chips.
For guests add: hot sauce, green onions, chiles
dearAlyssa: You are lazy, so instead of making the sauce yourself, use a mild red sauce in a can from the store. I think one big one does it.
Don't forget that spooning the mixture into the tortillas and putting them in the dish is a very messy process.

candiedYams.title: Candied Yams
directions: Cut yams in half
Boil yams until tender but firm. Peel after they cool
Slice yams about half inch thick
In fry pan, melt butter, sugar, salt, and water to make thick syrup.
Turn Yams in syrup, watch closely that they don’t burn.
dearAlyssa: Wear long-sleeve shirt or at least be careful for your arms in this one. Spitting hot sugar, ouch.

biscuits.title: Biscuits
ingredients: 1 cup buttermilk (substitute with almost 1 cup milk + 1 T vinegar
directions: Sift dry ingredients.
Cut in shortening.
Add milk, mix well.
Place on flour board, knead lightly.
Roll out, cut with cookie cutter.
Place on greased pan. 425° for 15 min
dearAlyssa: Jessi is the queen of these, go to her for questions.

tacoSoup.title: Taco Soup
ingredients: 1 pound ground beef (or turkey) (omit for vegan/vegetarian)
1 packet of taco seasoning or Sazon (con azafrán)
1 T tomato paste + ½ cup water
1 can chili con carne (or vegetarian chili)
directions: Cook ground meat in a large pot until brown. Pour out excess fat juice.
Add onion and garlic to pot and cook until onion pieces are barely translucent.
Add the following to the pot: beans (drained and rinsed), corn, chili, tomatoes, tomato sauce, salt, and seasoning.
Simmer on low until ready to eat.
dearAlyssa: I admit, I've modified the recipe quite a bit, but I like the results a lot! Original recipe called for: 2 cans of each beans and 2 cans of chili, 1 can of corn (not drained), 3-4 small cans of tomato sauce + 1 can of water (instead of tomato paste), 1 can chopped green chilies. Would probably make enough for 10 adults.
Use only one can of beans (total) for a smaller amount of soup.

Great to make if you have tomatoes that are going bad and are a little mushy. Chop these up and replace the can of diced tomatoes. If you end up doing fresher tomatoes, make sure to cook the soup long enough to soften them.

Original recipe called for cooking everything in a crockpot for several hours. Not really necessary, since everything is already cooked and seasoned. A crockpot is great for keeping warm, however, especially for a potluck or something.
This is a great meal to offer to a family with a new baby--it lasts for a long time in the fridge (or freezer), is easy to reheat in the microwave or on the stove, and is a nice and hardy meal.
And never forget: The World is Your Taco Soup. There's a lot you can do to get rid of stuff in your pantry and make this very tasty!

bananaBread.title: Banana Bread
bananaBread.tempTimeYield: Bake at 350° for: Large—60 min. Medium—50 min. Small—45 min. Recipe makes 2 large loaves
directions: Melt frozen bananas in microwave and mash.
Cream bananas with sugar; add butter, eggs, vanilla and milk.
Add dry ingredients (flour, soda, powder, salt)
Check with toothpick for doneness.
dearAlyssa: Isn't it nice to be a grownup and get to keep all the banana bread? When no one is going to give a loaf away as a gift without your okay?

cherryPie.title: Cherry Pie
ingredients: 2 cans Cherries ('Oregon Cherries, pitted red tart cherries in water') Save water!!
Keep ⅔ cup juice, drain the rest
directions: Drain cherries, save juice.
Pour cherries in pie dough, sprinkle on sugar and flour and stir in carefully, not poking the bottom.
Pour in juice, cover with top crust.
Bake at 400° for 30 min
dearAlyssa: Instead of stirring cherries in the dough, put it in a different bowl and mix with sugar in there. Just easier and less risk.

wings.title: Wings
directions: Mix above ingredients to make sauce.
Cut off wing tips and cut in half. Put wings in baking dish and pour sauce over.
Refrigerate for 2+ hours. (Overnight is best)
Bake at 350° for 1½ hours.

oysters.title: Grilled Oysters
ingredients: 3 or 4 oz beer (Shiner boch or lager preferred)
directions: Mix all ingredients (except oysters) in a small pot on low heat, until butter is melted.
Place whole oysters on grill with the deeper side of the shell face down.
Once they start bubbling and steaming, or if they open, take off. Drain, and open all the way, discarding the other shell. Put them back on grill.
Thoroughly mix the sauce repeatedly and sauce them oysters.
Once sauce is bubbling, carefully remove that hot little cup of sea juice. Serve!

pieCrust.title: Pie Crust
pieCrust.tempTimeYield: 1 top and bottom or two bottoms
directions: Sift flour and salt.
Cut in shortening well, add water and mix.
Roll once!
To make 2 pies (easier) 2 ½ x the recipe: 3 cups + 2 T flour, 2 ½ tsp salt, ½ cups + 2T water (5 oz), 10 oz shortening
dearAlyssa: This never seems enough for one full pie, let alone two bottoms.
For a full pie, do 1 ½ cups flour, and a heaping ½ cups of shortening (since 4oz = ½ cup). Add just a little more salt, but water can stay about the same.
Remember, bottoms need more dough than tops.

When rolling, knead ball until it's flat from your hands. Flip over and reflour really well--best way to get it to not stick when picking it up for the dish (via rolling back over the pin). If it sticks anyway, scrape up the tearing pieces with a flipper as you pick up the dough.
Don't forget about Andrea Young's special extra dessert: any extra crust, cut off with scissors, then put on a tin and top with cinnamon sugar.

chocolateChipCookies.title: Chocolate Chip Cookies
chocolateChipCookies.tempTimeYield: Bake at 350° for 10 minutes on a greased sheet. Makes 24 cookies
ingredients: 5 cup flour (recipe says 4-4½ cups but 5 for our oven)
directions: Cream margarine, shortening, brown and white sugar.
Add vanilla and eggs. Mix well.
Add flour, soda, salt, chocolate chips.
Bake at 350° for 10 minutes on a greased sheet
dearAlyssa: Jessi is also the queen of these too, I think the doubling quantities all come from her.

snickerdoodles.title: Snickerdoodles
directions: Cream shortening, sugar, and eggs.
Add flour, cream of tarter, soda, and salt.
Roll dough in quarter size balls and cover in a sugar & cinnamon mixture.
Bake at 375° for 10-12 minute
dearAlyssa: I do specifically remember making these with Grandma Harlan in the first house I remember her living in. My favorite was rolling the balls in the cinnamon-sugar mixture.

riceKrispieTreats.title: Rice Krispy Treats
ingredients: 1 whole box of 15 oz Rice Krispies
directions: Stir butter and marshmallows together until melted.
Add cereal.
Mix well and put on pan to cool.
dearAlyssa: Don't forget Mom's special trick of shaping the treats into the number of year you were turning, or something artistic like that. (Also don't forget that they're hot when you take them out of the pot.)

Holiday fun treat: make wreathes! Substitute corn flakes for Rice Krispies, and add green food dye to the marshmallows when melting. Cool in little doughnut shapes, and add Twizzler pull-n-peels that have been shaped into bows, and Red hots if you like (as holly berries).

ricePilaf.title: Rice Pilaf
ingredients: 1 handful dehydrated onion or 1 chopped onion
directions: Brown onion and RAW rice in oil until lightly golden. Rice should look a little transparent.
Add bullion, carrots, and water. Stir.
Put lid on when on medium heat for 15-20 min.
dearAlyssa: Your 'rice and beans' recipe stems from this one. Brown raw rice in oil and soy sauce, then add water to cook rice. Add black beans. Should this get its own recipe? Nah.

haystacks.title: Haystacks
haystacks.tempTimeYield: Makes 1 large cookie sheet of no-bake cookies
directions: Combine sugar, cocoa, butter, milk and peanut butter in sauce pan.
Bring to a boil and stir. Cook one minute.
Add oatmeal and vanilla and stir well.
Let mixture cool for a few minutes.
Scoop out with a spoon and drop onto cookie sheet.
Let them cool completely.
dearAlyssa: Make drop cookies very small so they're easier to pick up once they're dried.
This one can burn, esp at the beginning because your butter probably hasn't melted yet and your milk is trying to save the cocoa and sugar. Don't let it burn.

oatmealCake.title: Oatmeal Cake
directions: Cake: Cream sugars, shortening and eggs.
Add flour, salt, and cinnamon. Add boiling water then oats.
Bake cake for 35 min at 350°.
Frosting: Melt ingredients in a saucepan. Spread on cake and broil for 1-3 minutes. Watch carefully.

caramels.title: Caramels
ingredients: 2 cups cream (1 pint, heavy old fashioned or regular)
directions: Heat on medium to medium high. Stir the whole time!!!!
Mix sugar and syrup and bring to a boil, boil for 7 minutes
Add ⅓ cream. Boil 7 more minutes
Add ⅓ more cream, boil for 7 more minutes
Total = 21 minutes.
Add rest of cream, and boil until soft, firm ball stage--Critical! (Pour tiny bits in cold water to check texture)
Take off the heat and quickly stir in butter and vanilla.
Pour in buttered 9x9 pan
Cool in fridge
dearAlyssa: Do this with a team mate or your hand will get so, so, so, so tired.
Have everything ready before you start (especially if you're alone) so you don't get stuck not being able to stir.
The 'firm ball stage' is tricky. Stick on the softer side, because a firmer caramel is not as enjoyable to eat, even if it is easier to get out of the pan.
To wrap individual caramels, cut rectangles of wax paper/parchment paper wider than you think it needs to be. Twist each end the *same* direction, so that when you pull, it comes unraveled.
One day, I really ought to try a caramel apple with this recipe.

redOnionMushroomSalad.title: Red Onion Mushroom Salad
ingredients: ¾ lb mushrooms cut in half
½ lb bacon, cooked and crumbled
directions: Marinate dressing ingredients for a day
Mix salad ingredients, but hold cottage cheese and dressing to add before serving. May be too much dressing for salad so don’t pour all in.

creamyChickenSoup.title: Creamy Chicken Soup
ingredients: 8 cups chicken stock (8 bullion cubes or 2 T to 8 cups of water)
1 large bag frozen broccoli, cauliflower and carrots OR
directions: Melt margarine in saucepan; add flour and cook, stirring until smooth paste is formed.
Gradually stir in bullion broth and cook, stirring until sauce is smooth and thickened.
Add veggies. Simmer for 20 minutes.
Add chicken and cook until heated.
Bring to a boil.
Then add egg yolks and cream, stirring often. Do not boil after egg and cream are added.

strawberrySpinachSaladDressing.title: Strawberry Spinach Salad Dressing
ingredients: ½ cup raspberry vinegar (or reg vinegar and 1-2 drop red food coloring)
directions: Add to salad right before eating

honeyButteredPopcorn.title: Honey Buttered Popcorn
directions: Heat honey peanuts and butter until almost boiling.
Pour over popcorn in roasting pan or large deep pan. Stir to cover all kernels.
Put in oven at 275° for about 6 minutes or until caramelized, stirring often.

bakedBeans.title: Baked Beans
ingredients: 3 slices of bacon cut in ½
directions: Partially cook bacon- set aside.
Stir remaining ingredients together.
Put mixture in 2 qt dish. Lay bacon on top.
Bake at 350° oven for about 2 hours.

pepperkaker.title: Pepperkaker
pepperkaker.tempTimeYield: (Swedish Gingersnaps) “Makes Children Kind and Dear” 350° for 8-10 min
directions: Cream shortening, sugar, molasses and water together.
Add remaining ingredients and mix well.
Roll out thin and cut into heart shaped cookies.
Bake at 350° for 8-10 min on a greased cookie sheet.

Hold the pepperkaker in your hand. Make a wish, and then hit the center of the cookie with your knuckle. If it breaks into 3 pieces, give on piece to someone you love and eat the rest. Your wish will come true!

pumpkinPie.title: Pumpkin Pie
directions: Mix sugar, salt, cinnamon, ginger and cloves in a small bowl.
Beat eggs in large bowl. Stir in pumpkin and sugar-spice mixture.
Gradually stir in evaporated milk.
Pour into pie shells.
Bake in oven at 425° for 15 minutes. Reduce temperature to 350°, bake 40-50 minutes or until knife comes out clean.
Cool on wire rack for two hours.

applePie.title: Apple Pie
ingredients: 6-7 cored, sliced, skinless apples (green preferred—tarter the better!)
directions: Cook apples until tender and a little transparent, save water afterward!
Make sugar mixture, put half on bottom of crust.
Add apples, water, and second half of sugar mixture. Dot cubed butter and lemon juice then top the crust.
425˚ and 30-45 min
dearAlyssa: Cooking the apples and then adding water into pie always turns the apples into applesauce. Next time, try cooking the skins (instead of the apples themselves) to get 'apple water' and see if that helps the apple slices' texture.
Before you cut, core, and peel all the apples (which is easiest done with a countertop apple spiralizer), put the slices you've made in the empty pie dish until it's full. Now you have enough apples!
Consider trying mixing the apples with the sugar mixture before putting either into the pie. May make the flavor more even.

credit.text: Better Homes and Gardens Cook Book

ratatouille.title: Ratatouille Parisienne
directions: Prep all vegetables before starting: dice onion, cut zucchini into thick slices, cube tomatoes and eggplant into large pieces, and cut bell pepper into even squares.
Put oil (enough to sauté one onion) in the bottom of a large pot on medium to high heat. Sauté onion until slightly browned.

Add zucchini, tomatoes, eggplant, bell pepper. Stir to make sure nothing sticks to the pot. Add water; it will seem like very minimal water, but as the tomatoes cook, they will release their liquid and make up for it.

Add salt and herbs to flavor, which will likely be quite a bit—at least a tablespoon of each. Stir and lower temperature to low to medium heat. Add lid and simmer until vegetables are as soft as desired. As the veggies cook, they will condense and make more room in the pot.

credit.text: Monia Rivet Bonjean (translated to English by Alyssa Helgabones)

dearAlyssa: You always think that you should do just a little bit of herbes de provence, but you should do more than you think you should. Really give it a good shake. What, you think it's going to have 'too much lavender' taste to it? No such thing.

phadThai.title: Phad Thai
phadThai.tempTimeYield: Preps for one meal. Measurments are approximate and flexible according to taste
ingredients: 1 small handful of thin rice noodles
1 cup of cooked meat/tofu if desired
2 T roasted shelled unsalted peanuts, crushed/chopped
directions: Start by boiling water for the noodles. Put noodles in a flat bowl where they can be submerged with boiling water. Check noodle consistency every few minutes, pour out water once they are chewy, but not too soft.
Put cooking oil, garlic, and onion into a wok or large frying pan. Cook on med-high until fragrant. Add tomato and stir in.
Push all food to one side of pan and break eggs in pan (or prescramble in bowl). Scramble eggs.
Mix veggies and eggs together once eggs are cooked enough. Add noodles to wok. (It's okay if noodles aren't completely drained.) Add a small amount of water if the noodles are sticky.
Add cooked and chopped meat if desired.
Add in oyster sauce, soy sauce, and sugar. Cook for a minute, and adjust sauces to desired flavor.
Add green onions for a minute before taking off heat to take the onion-y edge off
Serve with peanuts and lime
dearAlyssa: Honestly, half of this recipe is your own reminders and instructions. Don't forget to take it REAL easy with the sauces--you often go overboard. Start small, you can always add more.
Recommend waiting until all food is prepared before starting the wok!!
Make sure you have everything before you start!!

massamanCurry.title: Massaman Curry
ingredients: 1 can of coconut milk (at least 6oz for one meal, recommend 12oz+ can)
2 T tofu or meat of choice
1 cup mixed veggies (pre-cooked potato or pumpkin, carrot, broccoli, mushroom)
directions: If non-vegetarian, cook meat of choice.
In wok (or large frying pan), fry the following over oil for 1-2 minutes, until fragrant: chili paste, curry powser, tomato, onion, tofu/meat, and 3T of canned coconut milk.
Add ½ cups of coconut milk, and mixed vegetables. Cook for 3-4 minutes
Add soy sauce, mushroom/oyster sauce, sugar, and lime juice. Remove from heat
Before serving, top with 1 T of coconut milk and roasted peanuts. Great with side of rice.
dearAlyssa: I've made this without chili powder (not spicy 😊) and using curry paste instead. Works great, though I wish it had a little more curry flavor in the end.
Get a mango for your extra coconut milk, and make extra rice--mango sticky rice for dessert. Yum!

pancakes.title: Pancakes
pancakes.tempTimeYield: Makes a full breakfast AND dinner for two adults
ingredients: ~3 T of fully melted butter/flavored oil
as much milk as it takes for consistency
directions: Whisk together dry ingredients (flour, powder, salt, sugar).
Add eggs, butter, and milk.
Keep your pan on medium heat, use butter on your pan for the best deliciousness.

SWEET PANCAKES: add directly to the pan: blueberries, flavored chips (chocolate chips, butterscotch chips, white chocolate chips, etc). Or don't! Serve with butter, jam, syrup, peanut butter, powdered sugar, cinnamon & sugar, whatever tickles your fancy!

Recipe has enough batter for breakfast AND dinner. BE CAREFUL when adding sweet-enhancing ingredients to your breakfast batter if you're going to have savory pancakes later! (No vanilla, cinnamon, etc.)

SAVORY PANCAKES: thin batter as desired for correct consistency. Add any of the following to batter: onion powder, garlic powder, cheese (cheddar, parmesan, mozzarella juice), sour cream, chives, etc. Possible meals: caprese with meatballs or fried chicken, black beans and corn, salad and meat in general. Use your imagination! The world is your pancake!
dearAlyssa: Just always have Brendon make these, because the way he fries the pancakes is just d e l i c i o u s.
And never forget: The World is Your Pancake.

zucchiniMuffins.title: Zucchini Muffins
zucchiniMuffins.tempTimeYield: 350°. 1 dozen+ muffins 20-30 min. 1 large bread pan + ½ doz muffins for ~40 and ~30 min respectively (when at the same time)
directions: Grate zucchini and preheat the oven to 350°F.
Beat the eggs in a large bowl. Mix in sugar and vanilla extract. Stir in the grated zucchini and the melted butter.
In a separate bowl, mix together flour, baking soda, baking powder, cinnamon, ground ginger, nutmeg, and salt.
Combine wet and dry ingredients. (Do not over-mix!) Stir in walnuts, raisins or cranberries if using.
Put in muffin tin and bake at 350° on the middle rack for 20-30 minutes. Muffins should be golden brown, the tops bounce back when you press on them, and have no gooey center.
dearAlyssa: I've modified the original recipe since each time I make this, I end up adding more salt and spices anyway. 🌰
Still working on turning it into zucchini bread (current recipe turns out very undercooked).

If the zucchini is a little older, it's much juicier. So when adding the zucc to the mix, pick it up and let the juice drain a little, but not too much. Trick is to let it stay moist, but don't just add a crap-ton of juice to it.

peachPie.title: Peach Pie
ingredients: 6 large peaches cut ¼ inches thick.
directions: Combine in a saucepan and cook over med heat, stirring constantly until thick: sugar, corn starch, salt, cinnamon, water, OJ, and crushed peach.
Cool sauce.
Gently combine vanilla, lemon juice, butter, and peaches.
Pour cooled sauce over peaches mixture and gently stir. Put in unbaked double crust. Bake on flat cookie sheet (so when it overflows into oven you don’t hate your life).
dearAlyssa: You've only made this once, and it was a long time ago. Check and make sure this recipe is still good! (The 'bake on cookie sheet' seems awfully suspicious to me that there's too much sauce.)

stirFryPotatoBellPepper.title: Stir Fry Potato and Bell Pepper
ingredients: ~½ tsp. sugar (offsets saltiness; balance sugar and salt to taste)
directions: Cut peppers and potatoes into 1x1 pieces, trying to make same size.

In fry pan on med-high, stir-fry potatoes over a small amount of oil. When the potatoes start to stick, add in a little bit of cold water, just barely enough to make them stop sticking and give them a little moisture to absorb.
Once potatoes start to become soft, add in the green peppers and mix together.
Add soy sauce, salt, and sugar to taste (sugar counterbalances the saltiness of everything else).
Remove from heat when veggies are just soft, but heated through.
dearAlyssa: Careful to not cook the potatoes too much before adding in the bell peppers, or they start to break apart at the end. No one wants stir fry mush!
This dish always reminds me of Avatar the Last Airbender, because I used to make this meal then watch it.

funeralPotatoes.title: Funeral Potatoes
ingredients: 1 can of cream of chicken soup
directions: Mix hash browns, cream of chicken soup, sour cream, onion, ½ cube of melted butter, and cheese together. Put evenly in a 9x13 pan.
Top with cornflakes and 2 T melted butter.
Bake uncovered at 350° for 30 minutes. Feeds 10.
dearAlyssa: I don't think I've ever made this specific recipe, but I know I love Funeral Potatoes. Never actually had them at a funeral, but it's one of the best Mormon casseroles to exist. I mean, who doesn't love cheesy potatoes?

playDough.title: Play Dough
directions: Boil water, then add salt, food coloring.
Add alum, baby oil, and flour.
Knead until complete.
dearAlyssa: I don't have alum in the house (had to look it up what it even was), and it seems a lot of people also use cream of tarter (though I'm not sure if it would work as a direct substitute in this recipe).
We still have play dough in the house, but when we next run out I'm trying this!

gak.title: Gak
ingredients: 1 level tsp talcum powder (NOT corn starch)
1-3 tsp borax solution (1 T of borax soap mixed with 1 cup water)
directions: Make Borax solution and shake until well dissolved.
In a separate paper cup (5 oz Dixie cup ok), measure and add Elmer’s glue. Add water, talcum powder, and food coloring. Stir well until lumps are all gone.
Add Borax mix until one glob is stuck to the stirrer (should be 2-3 tsp, but you may need to add more if all the glue mix isn’t transformed).
With your hands, pull the glob off the stirrer and squeeze out the excess fluid. Place in a zip-lock baggy or closable container so it will not dry out.
Be sure to clean up after as lots of ingredients stain!
dearAlyssa: Never tried this! Sounds like a great project for kiddos!

bathBomb.title: Bath Bombs
bathBomb.tempTimeYield: 4 large bath bombs. 24 hrs drying time.
ingredients: Color pigment (DIY makeup pigment or food coloring) (optional)
directions: In a medium bowl, mix together baking soda, citric acid, epsom salt, and corn starch.
If you want different colors/fragrances, separate into smaller bowls. Add tea and dry color pigment to desired look. Whisk to combine.

VERY slowly, add oils to dry ingredients, then any food coloring or extra water. (Important! The dry mixture is ready to start fizzing with any liquid added. Water and food coloring will make it fizz more, so do verrrry slowly.) Mix until combined, and the ingredients look like wet sand.
Molding the bomb: if using mini cupcake pan or ice tray, press mixture into mold and push down with flat surface if possible. Leave in to dry.

Molding the bomb: if using a global mold, fill each half of the mold, packing the mixture in slightly until it's overflowing. Press the halves together firmly. Let the filled mold sit for one minute. Lightly tap the mold and gently pull it apart to remove the bath bomb.
Let the bath bombs dry for 24 hours before enjoying in the tub.
dearAlyssa: Remember that any water added will take out some of the fizziness in the tub. Add more oil if you want to skip out on liquids (we don't add the water in the ingredients).
Food coloring will also take out fizziness--don't go crazy. A natural dye is going to be better for your water/skin/tub.

It's fun to match teas with essential oil fragrances and for purposes (chamomile/lavender for soothing sleep, mint for pain, black teas for energy, etc.). It's especially pretty to add tea to the bottom of the mold to help identify it.
Enjoy creating! The world is your bath bomb.

coffeeCake.title: Coffee 'Breakfast' Cake
directions: Combine flour, sugar, baking powder, salt in a medium sized bowl.
Combine egg, milk, and oil in another bowl.
Add wet and dry ingredients together, don't over stir.
Grease 9x9 or 8x8 pan and pour batter in.
Separately, combine topping ingredients, cutting in butter to make a crumble. Pour/sprinkle over batter.
Bake 25-30 minutes at 375°.
dearAlyssa: Crumble has already been multiplied, because lets be honest the crumble is the best part. I think last time I doubled the cake and poured it in a 9x13 pan. The crumble I think was still enough (but could have been more..?)
Heat a slice up and mix with vanilla ice cream for a yummy dessert!

pumpkinSeeds.title: Roasted Pumpkin Seeds
ingredients: 1 pumpkin's-worth amount of seeds, separated from pumpkin guts
directions: Scoop seeds out of a pumpkin, keeping separate from guts when possible. Rinse seeds in a collander.
Put seeds in bowl and add salt. Let salt dry seeds out for a few minutes.
Add olive oil, garlic powder, and onion powder. Amounts are undefined since number of seeds are variable. Season until it looks good.
Mix well until ingredients are evenly distributed. Lay seeds out on a cookie sheet lined with wax/parchment paper.
Cook at 350° for about 10 minutes.
'Stir' seeds by shimmying parchment paper and spreading out again. Turn temp down to 180° and cook until crispy, stiring each check so that seeds get flipped.

peanutButterPretzelTreats.title: Peanut Butter Pretzel Treats
directions: Mix peanut butter, salt, vanilla, powdered sugar and butter together.

Once you have a sturdy dough (helped with the fridge/freezer), roll out 1 T chunks and wrap around pretzel rods (leaving a handle). Place on a parchment-lined cookie sheet that will fit in your freezer.
Use all peanut butter dough and freeze sticks for about 2 hours.
Double boil white chocolate chips until very melted and liquidy. Do not try to melt twice.
Hold peanut butter stick over pot and spoon chocolate onto stick, covering peanut butter dough.
Place stick back on parchment-lined cookie sheet. Add sprinkles or other fun things for decoration. Place back in freezer until chocolate sets. Enjoy!
dearAlyssa: Original recipe was inspired by Netflix's 'Curious Creations of Christine McConnel' (season 1, episode 1) and calls shaping the sticks into bones. Just didn't work. Dough was too soft and chocolate was always too thick. Consider using literal melting white chocolate. If you try bones again, get creative--besides the default 'dog bone', you can make spine bones, eye balls, teeth, finger bones, wish bones, ribs, etc.

Still working on the recipe for the peanut butter dough; my first go the dough was too soft and I had to keep the bones in the freezer constantly. Consider removing butter to help make the dough stiffer. May need more powdered sugar.
I've found a 'no sugar added' peanut butter, and stevia-sweetened white chocolate. Could be made into a relatively low-carb treat!

royalIcing.title: Royal Icing
directions: Place the meringue powder and water in a large mixing bowl, and whip (with the whisk attachment) until foamy (about 3 minutes).
Add the powdered sugar, and whip on medium speed until very stiff and thick (the royal icing should hold a stiff peak).
Tint as needed with food coloring. If you use liquid food coloring, be careful, it could change consistency.
Thin with additional water, a drop at a time, to get the desired consistency.
dearAlyssa: Piping is tricky, and I definitely need more practice. Make sure to pipe and test--you need a slightly stiffer amount for outlining, and a thinner one for 'flooding'.

Trick to outlining is to hold your bag up higher than the cookie (instead of very close). You get straighter lines that way. Flooding IS easiest if you fill everything evenly. Tiny holes can be filled in with a toothpick, but it can sometimes be noticeably less frosting there.
I don't remember how long it takes to dry. A few hours at least though?
Don't add food coloring and use in tandem with Painted Sugar Cookies! (Under 'S' for 'Sugar')

sugarCookies.title: Sugar Cookies
directions: In a bowl, sift together flour, baking powder and salt; set aside. In a small bowl, lightly whisk together egg and vanilla extract; set aside.

In a large bowl, cream together softened butter and powdered sugar. With mixer running add in egg mixture and beat to combine; then add flour mixture little by little. Beat just until dough sticks to mixer, cookie dough gives slightly when gently pressed and dough does not stick to fingers.
Roll out dough between two sheets of parchment paper to 1/4 inch thickness. Use preferred cookie cutter and stamp out cookies.
Bake at 400° for 7-8 minutes.

paintedSugarCookies.title: Painted Sugar Cookies
directions: Make cookies according to Sugar Cookie recipe.
Make Royal Icing recipe and apply to cookies. Make sure icing has completely dried before attempting painting.
Create your colors on your palette, adding vodka to them to make more pastel.
Keeping brush as dry as possible, paint on the frosting of your cookies. Do not over-paint or frosting will dissolve.

roloYoloCookies.title: Jessi's Yolo Rolo Cookies
roloYoloCookies.tempTimeYield: 350° 12-14 minutes. Makes as many cookies as rolos (25-28)
directions: In a medium sized bowl, mix food cake, oil, and eggs. If dough is too dry, add a little bit of water.
Take small pieces of dough and surround a rolo until it's in the middle.
Roll dough ball in powdered sugar and place on cookie sheet.
Put in oven for 350° for 12-14 minutes.
dearAlyssa: Fun fact, these cookies won me a people's choice award at a Starbucks Web Engineering Cookie Bakeoff! They're just that good. And also easy to make!

spaghetti.title: Spaghetti Sauce
ingredients: A few good shakes of seasoning salt
3 leaves of fresh basil or equivalent dried basil
directions: In a pot on the stove, cook ground beef until brown, with onion and seasoning salt. Consider pouring out some beef fat before next step.
Add tomato sauce, then onion powser, garlic powder, basil, oregano, and sugar.
Simmer for as long as possible. Serve with spaghetti noodles (or for gluten free, zucchini noodles or spaghetti squash) and garlic bread.
dearAlyssa: I don't usually buy tomato sauce, instead I often put in cans of diced tomatoes (or dice up tomatoes that are going soft) and stick it in for content. I also use some tomato paste and water.
Optional add-ins: thyme, rosemary, olives, mushrooms... The world is your spaghetti sauce!

sevenLayerBars.title: Seven Layer Bars
directions: Melt butter; stir in crushed graham crackers. Pat crumb mixture evenly in bottom of an uncreased 13x9x2" baking pan.
Layer evenly, in order: chocolate pieces, butterscotch pieces, coconut, and walnuts.
Pour sweetened condensed milk evenly over all.
Bake at 350° for 30 minutes. Cool and cut into bars

credit.text: Better Homes and Gardens Cook Book

dearAlyssa: 1 package of graham crackers = more than 1½ cups of graham crackers, so do a little more butter. Nana's notes on the recipe say to do one package of graham crackers with one cube of butter, and to only cook it for 25 minutes.
